title: Refraction of Light
subject: integrated-science
description: Investigate how light bends when passing from one medium to another and verify Snell's Law
objectives: Define refraction and explain why it occurs
Apply Snell's Law to calculate angles of refraction
Measure angles of incidence and refraction accurately
Compare refraction in different media (glass, water)

theory.introduction: Refraction is the bending of light as it passes from one medium to another with a different optical density. This phenomenon occurs because light travels at different speeds in different materials.
keyPoints: Light travels fastest in vacuum (c = 3 × 10⁸ m/s)
Light slows down when entering denser media
The change in speed causes the light ray to bend
Light bends toward the normal when entering a denser medium
Light bends away from the normal when entering a less dense medium
The amount of bending depends on the refractive indices of the two media

snellsLaw.statement: The ratio of the sine of the angle of incidence to the sine of the angle of refraction is constant for a given pair of media

procedure.instruction: Place a rectangular glass block on white paper
procedure.safety: Handle glass carefully to avoid cuts

procedure.instruction: Trace the outline of the glass block on the paper
procedure.note: Keep the glass block stationary throughout the experiment

procedure.instruction: Draw a normal (perpendicular line) at the center of one side of the block
procedure.tip: Use a protractor to ensure the normal is exactly 90° to the surface

procedure.instruction: Direct a light ray toward the glass block at an angle (e.g., 30°) from the normal
procedure.warning: Do not shine laser pointers into eyes

procedure.instruction: Mark the path of the incident ray and the refracted ray inside the glass
procedure.note: Use dots to mark the ray path, then connect with a ruler

procedure.instruction: Measure the angle of incidence (θ₁) using a protractor
procedure.tip: Measure from the normal, not from the surface

procedure.instruction: Measure the angle of refraction (θ₂) inside the glass block
procedure.expected: Should be smaller than angle of incidence

procedure.purpose: Verify that Snell's Law holds for all angles

procedure.expected: Ratio should be approximately constant (≈ 1.5 for air-to-glass)

expected: Light bends toward the normal when entering glass from air
The angle of refraction is always less than the angle of incidence
Larger incident angles produce larger refracted angles
Different materials (water vs glass) produce different amounts of bending

analysis.verifyingSnellsLaw: For air-to-glass refraction, n₁ = 1.0 (air) and n₂ = 1.5 (glass). Using Snell's Law: sin(θ₁)/sin(θ₂) = n₂/n₁ = 1.5
analysis.graphing: Plot sin(θ₁) vs sin(θ₂). The graph should be a straight line passing through the origin, with slope equal to n₂/n₁

applications.description: Corrective lenses use refraction to focus light correctly on the retina, correcting nearsightedness, farsightedness, and astigmatism.
Multiple lenses refract light to magnify images and bring them into sharp focus.
Use total internal reflection (special case of refraction) to transmit light signals over long distances for internet and telecommunications.
Separate white light into its component colors (spectrum) because different wavelengths refract by different amounts (dispersion).
Mirages, twinkling stars, and the apparent bending of objects in water are all caused by refraction.
High refractive index (2.42) causes light to bend dramatically, creating the brilliant sparkle and fire.
Objects underwater appear closer and at different positions than they actually are due to refraction at the water-air boundary.

safety: Never shine bright lights or lasers directly into eyes or at reflective surfaces that could redirect into eyes
Use only low-power laser pointers (Class 2 or below)
Handle glass blocks carefully - edges can be sharp
If using water containers, ensure they are stable to prevent spills
Clean up water spills immediately to prevent slipping
Work in a well-lit room to reduce eye strain
Report any broken glass or equipment damage immediately

extendedLearning.totalInternalReflection: When light travels from a denser to less dense medium at angles greater than the critical angle, it reflects completely back into the denser medium. This is used in fiber optics and diamond cutting.
extendedLearning.dispersion: Different wavelengths (colors) of light refract by different amounts in the same medium, causing white light to separate into a spectrum. This is why prisms create rainbows.
extendedLearning.criticalAngle: The angle of incidence in the denser medium for which the angle of refraction is 90°. Beyond this angle, total internal reflection occurs. For glass-air boundary: θc = sin⁻¹(1/n) ≈ 42°
